posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
We’ve been a Python team for several years now, but are trying to use the new REV MAXSwerve modules. I took a stab at converting the Java example code REV provides but haven’t had much luck making it work yet. I was hoping someone else had started playing with the modules and was using Python too and could provide some help. Some of our issues are that we’ve been a TimedRobot team for most of the time and I’m having trouble trying to debug Command mode.

Thanks

I’m working on a swerve library for Python right now. The REV branch of it is a bit broken rn, but I’m planning on merging bug fixes in the coming days.

You can find it here ( GitHub - EWall25/swervelib: Swerve library and base code ). I’ll let you know when I fix the REV code.

link_counts.title: GitHub - EWall25/swervelib: Swerve library and base code

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: If there are specific pieces you are having issues converting, you can post them and maybe we can help.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Right now I’m having issues debugging command mode. This is our first foray into command mode and having issues figuring out how to verify what the scheduler is doing. I’ve added prints here and there and that helps, but I just don’t have a great handle on it yet. I’m going to go back to the REV Java code today and strip down the python I have to a bare minimum version of the Java code. If I can get a more specific issue I’ll certainly ask.

Thanks!

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
So I think there might be weirdness with the REVlib absolute encoder in the Python wrappers.

Our code is here: GitHub - South-Doyle-Robotics/python-swerve-port and is basically a port of the REV java example from here: GitHub - REVrobotics/MAXSwerve-Java-Template

Right now our code is basically in debug and only one module is getting any sort of update and the update is just trying to zero the turn motor. The turn motor is basically psycho spinning. If I stopping using the absolute encoder to try to set the initial position, it at least stops spinning.

I’m currently looking at the code at MAXSwerve-Java-Template/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/MAXSwerveModule.java at main · REVrobotics/MAXSwerve-Java-Template · GitHub lines 70-78 that  set up the absolute encoder and PID controller.

I was playing with the Python equivalent in an interactive Python interpreter on the driver station and noticed some odd behavior. Maybe it’s because I’m just running locally, not on a robot? But this seems odd to me.

from rev import CANSparkMax, CANSparkMaxLowLevel, SparkMaxPIDController, RelativeEncoder from rev._rev import AbsoluteEncoder, SparkMaxAbsoluteEncoder turn = CANSparkMax(2, CANSparkMaxLowLevel.MotorType.kBrushless) te = turn.getAbsoluteEncoder(SparkMaxAbsoluteEncoder.Type.kDutyCycle) tp = turn.getPIDController() te.setInverted(True) <REVLibError.kParamMismatchType: 9> tp.setPositionPIDWrappingEnabled(True) <REVLibError.kParamMismatchType: 9> tp.setPositionPIDWrappingMinInput(0.0) <REVLibError.kParamMismatchType: 9> tp.setP(1) <REVLibError.kOk: 0>

The kParamMismatchType: 9 return from the three commands has me wondering if that’s part of the problem. Am I doing something wrong or is something not happy in the Python REV wrappers? The Java code compiles and runs fine.

I don’t have easy access to the robot until tomorrow so can’t try this on the Rio itself.

Thoughts?

Thanks!

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: I didn’t look terribly closely, but your code looks right at a glance. REV did just push an update with something about absolute encoders, so if you upgrade to robotpy-rev 2023.1.3.1 that might just fix it?

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Yeah, we will certainly try the upgrade but I don’t know that the encoder fixes are related to the issue we’re seeing. REV’s java code works fine and it uses the absolute encoders in what I think is the same way we’re using them in Python, so dunno.

Thanks -Brian

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
REV’s Java simulation code mildly worked last year, whereas their C++ code didn’t. It’s not a stretch to believe that their C++ support isn’t as good as their Java support.

Another good test here would be to compile their C++ example and see if it works. If it works, RobotPy is broken. If it doesn’t work, REV’s C++ code is broken.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
Lol, so the problem is the error you didn’t report (but you mentioned it in a comment at python-swerve-port/swerve.py at 61d318a47dcf4cf8355c827e92c23067cb589786 · South-Doyle-Robotics/python-swerve-port · GitHub ).

The swerve thing is feedback driven, so have to set the feedback device otherwise the code isn’t going to work. I tried it, and got presumably the same error you ran into:

That would be a bug in RobotPy. We had omitted the CANSensor base of the encoder for whatever reason, so it isn’t accepted here, but obviously it should be. I’ll see if I can address it tonight, but I won’t be home for a few hours.

I’ve updated the library to work with Spark MAXs on the merge_ctre_rev branch ( GitHub - EWall25/swervelib at merge_ctre_rev ). Currently, it’s made for the SDS setup of two NEOs and a CANCoder, but it should be able to be adapted well enough. In the coming days, I’m going to add a proper README and merge these changes into master.

It looks like you have your own code mostly worked out, but if you ever want to take a look at my library it would be greatly appreciated! Best of luck in getting your drivetrain working!

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
virtuald:

That would be a bug in RobotPy.

Will be fixed in robotpy-rev 2023.1.3.2

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked: I’d be happy to try to merge our two codebases as soon as ours is actually working. Sounds like we might be really close with the fix virtuald just pushed.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked: Awesome, thanks! We will update and try this out this morning. I’m sure there are some bugs in our code still but hopefully we can get past them now.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
We’ve updated to the latest REV wrappers and re-enabled the two PID setFeedbackDevice calls. I also checked on the Rio that the setInverted and setWrapping calls return OK rather than kParamMismatchType, so right now we don’t seem to have any (silent) warnings or errors.

However, the code behaves exactly the same way. The turn motors just spin at high speed in circles. We’ve tried a bunch of things but nothing changes the behavior. I’m not sure what to try next at this point.

The code is pretty hacked up at this point but I pushed the latest back to github.

Right now I’m trying to figure out why the turn motor spins in the drive() method of swervedrivetrain.py, but the print in that only happens at robot init, not during teleop.

Thanks -Brian

I believe I understand why the turn motor spins, but the print only occurs once. This is how you set your default command at the moment:

setDefaultCommand is a method that takes a command as its sole argument. So, your code should look more like this:

This creates a RunCommand that runs the function inside of it every iteration. Forgive me for potentially overexplaining, but lambda creates a single line function that can be passed as an argument to the constructor of RunCommand .

To explain the code’s previous behavior, you were calling the drive method once during robot init, and that set your motors to run. Once a motor controller like a Sparm MAX begins running, it won’t stop until you tell it to.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Thanks, we were wondering about that right before I had to leave today. It finally donned on us that the command probably wasn’t running but I didn’t have a chance to modify the code.

Command based is new to us so.

Thanks.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
EthanWall:

Unfortunately, that gives us: default commands must require their subsystem

Googling around for that has not been super helpful since all the responses are java. Is there good documentation (not just doxygen) for command mode somewhere that we can read?  There’s some good examples for Java but command mode definitely requires far more syntactical sugar and I don’t know Java well enough to figure out python equivalents.

Thanks for your help so far.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Ok, got past this at least by adding a [self.drivetrain] after the lambda  -     self.drivetrain.setDefaultCommand(commands2.RunCommand(lambda: self.drivetrain.drive(0, 0, 0), [self.drivetrain]))

Now, drive is called all the time. Woot! However, the motors still spin in a circle, even though X/Y/omega are supposed to be 0. Boo!

So, not sure where to go next. I was reasonably confident in our swerve drivetrain and swerve module code, but apparently there must still be an issue there.

Thanks

I noticed that your drive turn motor isn’t inverted, but your turn encoder is. When you say spinning in circles, do you mean that the wheel spins in one direction without stopping? If so, then inverting the turn motor might fix your issue. The motor might be spinning in a negative direction, while the encoder reports positive rotation, causing the wheel to never reach its desired angle.
